review_title: Not what it's cracked up to be
pros: If you are on-site, you do get lots of "free" amenities. There are secondary perks like hardware tests and access to training programs. Depending on your team, you are allowed to be pretty autonomous, working flexible hours and on projects you are interested in.
cons: The compensation model is completely broken. If you work remote, you get paid less if you don't live in California, which doesn't make any sense at all. If remote you also have no access to any of the perks that are supposedly awesome - no free food, no snacks, no daycare, no workout rooms, no busses, no massage chairs, no massages, and no swag. They don't really care about their employees - they just want to make sure you stay where they can keep track of you.

review_title: Great overall company culture, but it comes down to your team
pros:
Excellent employee benefits and competitive salary (usually the top of the market)
Lots of opportunity for professional growth and internal mobility
Perks are fantastic (free food, onsite gym, shuttle service, etc.)
cons: I'm sure you've read all the great things about working at Google, such as the obvious like perks and salary. But do your due diligence when going through the interview process to get a feel for your team and manager. Ultimately, that is what is going to shape your day to day experience at the company. I ultimately left after a bad re-org that left me doing the work of 4-5 people by myself that was outside the scope of my level, yet I wasn't promoted when I brought it up to my manager.

review_title: Still an amazing place to work, beware of entitlement
pros:
1. Great work/life balance. There's not many companies I know that have a consistent a 40hr work week, and pay top salary.
2. Cool projects to work on. Good balance between research & development. (See caveats below though.)
3. Supportive, healthy, psychologically safe work environment. Google cares a ton about how we work, and how we work together. The bottom-up culture also means that we have a lot of self-determination and don't feel like we're at the mercy of our management.
4. Super easy internal mobility. Lots of us change teams every couple of years. Google has so many different types of work that you won't feel you're "stuck" -- as long as you like working at Google overall, then you'll be able to find something interesting.
5. It's Google! Having Google on your resume opens doors to other opportunities, and it's great for networking too since generally your colleagues will be top of their field.
cons:
1. Entitlement. I make literally 5x as much as I ever dreamt. The comp is insane at FAANG companies like Google. But people here constantly complain about salary, the quality of the free food, why they have to work 5 days a week.... these are sometimes the same people who work 20 hrs a week. The amount of entitlement is insane here -- yes, we're the best of the best and we deserve a lot. But the culture and perks tend to pamper us.

2. Not all teams and projects have fulfilling work. There's lots of options, but choose carefully. Maybe you're happy getting paid to do nothing, on a team that has no visibility, so that you can "rest and vest" and coast. But, this will leave you woefully unprepared for your next job.... any company will hire you after Google, but that doesn't mean you'll do well at any company, particularly if you go to a more fast paced environment.

pros: Interview is fairly easy if you prepare for it. Its very difficult to get fired. Products have so much existing market share that there is very little risk of them getting disrupted even if serious errors are made quarter after quarter.
cons:
Google makes most of its own tooling/libraries/etc and those things break a lot more often than they should - it creates a sense of powerlessness and insignificance because work is often impeded or interrupted when it isn't even your fault and your only recourse is to wait for it to be fixed. Most of the best/preferred technologies are not shared outside the company which limits how much your skill set can transfer to elsewhere.

Policy on covid makes no sense, is highly disruptive to productivity and I don't think its going to get better - most of the world has moved on but Google is still living in a time capsule from early 2020 when it comes to covid.

pros:
I was a TSE at GCP. I have listed the pros and cons of the role below. As you can see, the cons outweigh the pros, which is why I left for a different role within Google.

1. Great way to get your foot in the door in Google. The interview process is relatively easy (compared to SWE) and they are hiring at a fast pace. (UPDATE - Recently there has been news that they are limiting hiring in the USA and have even let go of some employees)

2. Great way to learn how a growing Cloud enterprise operates.

3. Get the Google brand on your work experience.
cons:
1. Not really a technical role. You basically resolve customer issues. There is almost no coding. This is great for people who are not technically inclined but still want to get paid well for support work. But it drained me as I did not feel challenged and had nothing to actually learn as I believe that the only way to learn is to implement things. I am surprised by how many of my fellow TSEs (with MS degrees) were OK with this sort of work.

2. No opportunities to learn and grow by building a project from scratch. This may seem like a copy of the first point but it's not. Before joining Google Cloud, I had 4 years of experience as a Software Engineer and a Data Engineer at multiple companies. In all of them, you either had a new or relatively-new project that you got assigned to and you contributed to its development. Watching your project grow and get to production is an important part of being an engineer and why I love my line of work. But this is not possible when you are flooded with cases that you need to resolve. Google does allow 20% of your time to work on projects outside of your work, but unless you come up with an idea to benefit your own sub-organization (i.e. Cloud Support), you cannot really include that work in your year-end performance review. I am observing a pattern where GCP is focussing more on hiring interns straight out of college. The good thing is that it prevents them from hiring experienced over-qualified engineers for support work. The bad thing is that many new engineering graduates will accept the fact that solving customer cases is true engineering work and will never venture outside of this proverbial well.

3. Lot of churn in employees. Based on the above 2 points, employees are dissatisfied. I have seen quite a few people either leave Google or move to a different role after less than 2 years. This reinforces my belief that I am not the only one who feels the same way about this role. This is even true even for senior leadership. During my time working there, I saw a lot of changes in the leadership structure. 

4. Customers are not the most patient people in the world. This is especially true when they are facing an issue and they have asked you to resolve it. I had a particularly bad experience when on a customer call, the customer talked to me like I was a waiter who had made a mistake with his order. Not all customers are like this, but it takes only one to make you rethink your career choices.

pros:
Pro: Animals Welcome.

Many Google offices are animal friendly. The most extreme example is their California office which makes use of goats to keep their lawns neatly grazed, but many other offices also encourage their staff to bring their dogs to work, to improve wellbeing. Another initiative also provides pushbikes to ride around the Google Campus in an eco-friendly way.
cons:
Con: Work-life balance – not always balanced.

Many modern American companies have developed a contrived culture of lingering at work. Ambitious, new or young talent may end up hanging out at the office outside of work hours, often working or learning. This can develop into peer pressure to spend a lot of time at the office. Apart from coffee shops and libraries, some places have “sleep pods” for that swift power nap to help you keep going for longer. The Toronto Office even has a crazy golf putting green on the roof!

job_title: Senior Technical Recruiter Or Recruiting Manager in Austin, TX
pros: Google has incredible resources for learning high-tech and managing teams. There is outstanding onboarding, process documentation, and shadowing for new joiners. Google also has a strong work-life balance, anchoring meetings to midday to respect national timezones. The community of individuals is top-notch- amazingly smart, driven, and courteous colleagues.
cons: Given the scale of the operation, it's very hard to create change. The best opportunities and problems are often "gifted" down from managers to select individuals who are on fast promotion trajectories. Challenges are often framed so positively, it can feel impossible to ask the "real question," criticize efforts, or swim upstream. I saw individuals sent a strong message with their ratings for challenging the status quo. At times, this can feel toxic and insurmountable. The key here is aligning to strong managers who are transparent and supportive so you can get tapped for meaningful work, find a safe space for challenging assumptions, and get buy-in for your ideas.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Tel Aviv-Yafo
pros:
- Amazing benefits.
- Highly talented people.
- Friendly work environment, friendly management.
- Company strives to improve itself and acts on internal criticism.
- Accessibility to awesome technologies and insider information.
cons:
- Most projects aren't exciting.
- Lots of technical dept and bureacracy.
- Your performance is largely valued on how well you write about it, not on it actually being great.
- Hard to transfer teams if your performance doesn't exceed expectations.
- Internal work tools are dated, cumbersome and lacking compared to those in the industry.
- Mixed messages when it comes to work-life balance: management stresses the importance of work-life balance and gives us the freedom to put life first, but in practice this generally means your performance can worsen compared to your peers which influences your career path there.
- HR responds slowly for most bureacratic requests.

pros: An abundance of free perks: good, gyms, discounted massages, great offices
cons:
Google makes it incredibly hard to change job ladders. I have done an absurd amount of 20% projects across various teams to sharpen my skill sets, and have been looking for a new non-administrative job for three years now (of my nearly four year tenure) and have not gotten one offer. I have more than seventy closed applications for roles that I am more than qualified for. It has come down to me and another candidate numerous times now, and I’m constantly told that I do not have enough experience, when I clearly do. 

If you don’t want to grow your career in a significant way, this is a great place, but if you do, you should think twice about working here.

job_title: Sr. Visual Designer in Austin, TX
pros:
Over the past 3-4 years, Google has been making an important effort to become a more equitable, diverse, and inclusive place to work. It allows employees to express their opinions to help improve the company culture overall. The benefits are solid, and pay is competitive. The stock price aint bad either. 

There is lots of opportunity to bring Visual Design to life at Google, especially since Google Material evolves every few years.
cons:
Due to Google being such a large company with several (hundred?) different product teams, there is always an opinion. ;) If you enjoy heavy XFN collaboration and okay with lots of constructive feedback over tiny details, then Google is for you. 
However, If you are the type of designer who wants to design and launch a product quickly without friction, Google may not be the best fit for you. Getting products launched at Google does take time, because everyone needs to negotiate, align, and agree as one large XFN product team. I appreciate the democratic process when making design decisions vs. being told how a design should be, but it may take a long time to get a product launched because of it, and it may not even see the light of day. If you have patience, Google is for you. If you do not, then Google may not be the place for you. :)

review_title: A parallel reality for tech, as long as you can handle the politics
pros:
- Amazing in-house infrastructure that you can learn a lot from
- Very talented colleagues
- Plenty of ownership over what you do (compared to companies that aggressively "follow the market")
cons:
- Becoming more and more opaque (esp. upper management), openly destroying the transparent and communicative culture that used to predominate
- Lots of incentives to rush things in time for perf/promotion cycles since management mostly cares about new shiny launches (just see how little users trust Google at this point to keep their products alive or do good customer service)
- Massive company = lots of managers and arbitrary bureaucratic power. It's up to luck whether you can escape internal politics and have a good experience or get stuck in a toxic team
- Very very political environment which can be really draining
- Even in Europe, American views on identity and race trump all (if you're white, it's irrelevant if you came from a poor family in a post-soviet country, you need to check your privilege)

That mindset is rewarded at Perficient.

review_title: Google is a great place to work
pros:
basic affiliation - people are impressed when they learn you work for Google.

- compensation - it's no secret how far ahead of market comp they are. Ask any non-Google company in the valley that has made an offer to a Googler.

- the quality of people around you - have we beaten this one to death?

- the borderline unbelievable perks. See articles about their life insurance benefits, for just one extreme example.
cons:
The first 3 months at Google are a honeymoon, the first 2 years are great, then it goes downhill from there.

Performance management is a massive unsolved problem. There is the expectation that the expectations you have to meet keep growing forever so it's hard to take a break. Even if you don't get promoted, expectations grow because "you're more experienced".

cons: The stress was completely overwhelming for me, I felt like projects had such a short turnaround that I was constantly trying to make up for it by apologising to management and working later than my stated hours. I left this job so that I could move into a more laidback environment

review_title: Great Place to Work, But The Grind is Real
pros:
Incredibly supportive colleagues and direct managers, however this may depend on the team you're on. 

Fantastic Benefits and perks
cons:
While they acknowledge impostor syndrome and tell you not to worry, there is an immense amount of pressure to succeed and hit targets ASAP after ramp, which leads to a brutal work/life balance. 

Processes and org structure were constantly shifting, which makes it difficult to plan for future performance.
